articles.headline: Trump Supports Plan to Cut Legal Immigration by Half
articles.snippet: Legislation would favor immigrants based on skills and education, while curtailing those brought into the country through family ties.
articles.abstract: Legislation would favor immigrants based on skills and education, while curtailing those brought into the country through family ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump embraced a proposal on Wednesday to slash legal immigration to the United States in half within a decade by sharply curtailing the ability of American citizens and legal residents to bring family members into the country.

articles.headline: As Washington Tries to Protect Tech, China Could Fight Back
articles.snippet: As the Trump administration takes on Beijing over intellectual property, global trade rules could favor China.
articles.abstract: As the Trump administration takes on Beijing over intellectual property, global trade rules could favor China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Trump administration moves to take on China over intellectual property, Washington will find it has limited firepower. Beijing has a strong grip on American technology companies, and global trade rules could favor China.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Amazon’s Jobs Fair Sends Clear Message: Now Hiring Thousands
articles.snippet: Amazon’s nationwide jobs fair on Wednesday offered a vivid illustration of its ascendance and seemingly insatiable need for workers to fuel its growth.
articles.abstract: Amazon’s nationwide jobs fair on Wednesday offered a vivid illustration of its ascendance and seemingly insatiable need for workers to fuel its growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROMEOVILLE, Ill. — Brandon Williams arrived at an Amazon fulfillment center here, about an hour outside of Chicago, around 7:30 a.m. on Wednesday, one of thousands across the country who turned up for the company’s first Jobs Day. While he appeared to wilt slightly during the five hours he waited before an M.C. summoned him for a tour, his enthusiasm did not wane.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Behind the Sudden Death of a $1 Billion Secret C.I.A. War in Syria
articles.snippet: The shuttering of the C.I.A. program, one of the most expensive efforts to arm and train Syrian rebels since the 1980s, has forced a reckoning over its successes and failures.
articles.abstract: The shuttering of the C.I.A. program, one of the most expensive efforts to arm and train Syrian rebels since the 1980s, has forced a reckoning over its successes and failures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The end came quickly for one of the costliest covert action programs in the history of the C.I.A.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Adam Goldman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Wall Street, Climbing Sharply, Skips Washington’s ‘Soap Opera’
articles.snippet: The stock surge of recent months, ignited by policy prospects, is now driven by strong earnings and other factors that seem impervious to politics.
articles.abstract: The stock surge of recent months, ignited by policy prospects, is now driven by strong earnings and other factors that seem impervious to politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite the disorder in Washington — with a revolving door at the White House and roadblocks on Capitol Hill — Wall Street and corporate America are booming.

articles.headline: Affirmative Action Battle Has a New Focus: Asian-Americans
articles.snippet: A lawsuit against Harvard raises the issue of whether there has been discrimination against Asian-Americans in the name of creating a diverse student body.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit against Harvard raises the issue of whether there has been discrimination against Asian-Americans in the name of creating a diverse student body.
articles.lead_paragraph: By most standards, Austin Jia holds an enviable position. A rising sophomore at Duke, Mr. Jia attends one of the top universities in the country, setting him up for success.
articles.byline: By Anemona Hartocollis and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Trump Keeps His Conservative Movement Allies Closest
articles.snippet: The White House has spent considerable time and effort cultivating the right, the one constituency it knows it cannot afford to alienate.
articles.abstract: The White House has spent considerable time and effort cultivating the right, the one constituency it knows it cannot afford to alienate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sometimes he just wants to know how he’s doing, like a maître d’ checking in after a meal. “How’s this playing?” President Trump asked Fox News’s Sean Hannity over dinner in the private residence of the White House the other night, a few hours after visiting Wisconsin to announce a deal to create thousands of new factory jobs.

articles.headline: What Would It Take for Trump to Get His Corporate Tax Wish?
articles.snippet: Capping the top rate at 15 percent would require a willingness to ditch tax subsidies favored by special interests, including real estate developers.
articles.abstract: Capping the top rate at 15 percent would require a willingness to ditch tax subsidies favored by special interests, including real estate developers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For President Trump, 15 is the magic number.

articles.headline: As Brexit Nears, ‘Discounters’ Gain Ground in U.K. Supermarket Wars
articles.snippet: As customers face pressure on their disposable income, two German supermarkets with a reputation for low prices are winning market share in Britain.
articles.abstract: As customers face pressure on their disposable income, two German supermarkets with a reputation for low prices are winning market share in Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — At the vast Sainsbury’s grocery store in south London’s Tooting Broadway neighborhood, a basket of milk, eggs, bread, cornflakes and butter will cost shoppers four pounds and 70 pence, or about $6.15. A short walk away at Aldi and Lidl — two German discount grocery stores — those same items amount to £3.92.

articles.headline: China’s Internet Censors Play a Tougher Game of Cat and Mouse
articles.snippet: New efforts to tighten online controls show a shift in the way Beijing regulates content, with potential implications for researchers and businesses.
articles.abstract: New efforts to tighten online controls show a shift in the way Beijing regulates content, with potential implications for researchers and businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The shutdown was unusual, and came without warning.
